title: IPv4 Addressing
description: Understanding subnetting, subnet masks, CIDR notation, and IP address structure

keyConcepts.title: IPv4 Address Structure
keyConcepts.description: Every IPv4 address consists of two parts: the network portion (identifies the subnet) and the host portion (identifies the specific device within that subnet).

keyConcepts.title: Subnet Mask
keyConcepts.description: A 32-bit value that determines which portion of an IP address is the network and which is the host. Written in dotted decimal (e.g., 255.255.255.0) or CIDR notation (e.g., /24).

keyConcepts.title: CIDR Notation
keyConcepts.description: Classless Inter-Domain Routing notation uses a slash followed by the number of network bits (e.g., /24, /27, /30). Makes subnet masks easier to read and write.

keyConcepts.title: Subnetting
keyConcepts.description: The process of borrowing host bits to create additional networks. Increases the number of subnets but reduces the number of hosts per subnet.

keyConcepts.title: VLSM (Variable Length Subnet Masking)
keyConcepts.description: Allows different subnet masks within the same network, enabling efficient IP address allocation by tailoring subnet sizes to specific requirements.

keyConcepts.title: ANDing Process
keyConcepts.description: Layer 3 devices perform bitwise AND operation between IP address and subnet mask to determine the network address, which is used for routing decisions.

importantPoints: IPv4 addresses have two components: network portion and host portion
Subnet mask determines the boundary between network and host bits
Network address: all host bits = 0 (not assignable to hosts)
Broadcast address: all host bits = 1 (not assignable to hosts)
Total addresses - 2 (network + broadcast) = usable host addresses
Borrowing bits creates subnets: 2^(borrowed bits) = number of subnets
More borrowed bits = more subnets but fewer hosts per subnet
ANDing determines if destination is local or remote
VLSM allows different-sized subnets in the same network
/30 = 2 usable hosts (2 host bits: 4 - 2) - used for point-to-point links
